q: What are the symptoms of urethritis?
a: Symptoms of urethritis include pain or a burning feeling when you pee, white or cloudy discharge from the vagina or penis, and an irritated or sore tip of the penis.

q: How long does it take for symptoms of urethritis to appear after having sex?
a: If urethritis is caused by a sexually transmitted infection (STI), it can take a few days or weeks for symptoms to appear after having sex.

q: What should I do if I think I have urethritis or a sexually transmitted infection (STI)?
a: Go to a sexual health clinic or see a GP if you think you might have urethritis or a sexually transmitted infection (STI). It's important to get it treated to avoid it spreading to other people.

q: What tests may be done if I have symptoms of urethritis?
a: If you have symptoms of urethritis, you may have a swab test to take a sample from the urethra or a urine test. You may also be offered tests for other sexually transmitted infections (STIs).

q: What will happen if the test shows that I have urethritis?
a: If the test shows that you have urethritis, anyone you've had sex with recently should be contacted and asked to get tested and treated if needed. The sexual health clinic can advise you about this.

q: How is urethritis usually treated?
a: Urethritis is usually treated with antibiotics. It may take a week or two for your symptoms to disappear completely. Avoid having sex until you and any sexual partners have finished treatment and the symptoms have gone.

q: What can cause urethritis?
a: Urethritis is usually caused by a sexually transmitted infection (STI) such as chlamydia. It can also be caused by damaging the urethra or sometimes no cause can be found.

q: How can I avoid getting urethritis?
a: You can reduce your chances of getting urethritis by using a condom every time you have vaginal or anal sex, using a condom or a latex or plastic square to cover the vagina during oral sex, and not sharing sex toys or washing them before anyone else uses them.

q: What complications can arise from urethritis?
a: Although complications are rare, urethritis can sometimes cause reactive arthritis, epididymitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) if left untreated.

q: What is reactive arthritis?
a: Reactive arthritis is a condition where the immune system attacks the joints or eyes, resulting in joint pain and conjunctivitis. It can be a complication of urethritis.

q: What are the symptoms of urethritis?
a: Symptoms of urethritis include pain or a burning feeling when you pee, white or cloudy discharge from the vagina or penis, and an irritated or sore tip of the penis.

q: What tests are done to diagnose urethritis?
a: To diagnose urethritis, you may have a swab test or a urine test. A swab test involves taking a sample from the urethra, and a urine test requires not peeing for at least 2 hours before providing a sample.

q: How is urethritis treated?
a: Urethritis is usually treated with antibiotics. It may take about a week or two for the symptoms to disappear completely.

q: What causes urethritis?
a: Urethritis is usually caused by sexually transmitted infections (STIs) such as chlamydia. It can also be caused by damaging the urethra or can have no identifiable cause.

q: How can urethritis be avoided?
a: To reduce the chances of getting urethritis, it is recommended to use a condom during vaginal or anal sex, use protection during oral sex, and avoid sharing sex toys without proper cleaning and condom use.

q: What are the potential complications of urethritis?
a: Although rare, complications of urethritis can include reactive arthritis, epididymitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) which can lead to joint pain, testicle infection, and reproductive health issues respectively.

q: When should I seek medical advice for urethritis?
a: It is recommended to seek medical advice if you think you might have urethritis or a sexually transmitted infection (STI). Prompt treatment can help prevent spreading the infection to others.

q: What happens during an appointment for urethritis?
a: During an appointment for urethritis, you may undergo tests such as a swab test or a urine test. Healthcare professionals may also offer tests for other sexually transmitted infections (STIs).

q: How long does it take for urethritis symptoms to disappear after treatment?
a: After starting antibiotics, it may take about a week or two for urethritis symptoms to disappear completely. It is important to complete the full course of treatment.

q: Can urethritis be transmitted without symptoms?
a: Yes, if a person has urethritis caused by a sexually transmitted infection (STI) but has no symptoms, they can still pass on the infection to others unknowingly. Regular testing can help identify and treat infections early.
